data.name: Custom format
data.description:
In this kata you'll have to create your own string formatting function.

# Arguments

Your function must take a string, and then unknown count of parameters.
Every time you encounter `%x` for `y`-th time, you must print `y`-th element with type of `x`.

#### Here are types according to `%x` representation:

| Type     | Representation |
| -------- | -------------- |
| Integer  | %d             |
| Float    | %f             |
| Char     | %c             |
| String   | %s             |

# Return Type
the return type will be a `string` that is formatted as described before.

# Examples
```
  format_string("Hello, %s World!", "My") => 
      "Hello, My World!"
      
  format_string("%d is my %s number%c", 10, "favourite", '!') => 
    "10 is my favourite number!"
    
  format_string("This is normal\n") =>
    "This is normal\n"
```

### Note

#### 1. 
It's 100% that counts of `y` is always same with count of parameters with `%x` type. If `x` does not match with any type shown on the table, just print `%x`. 

#### 2.
Any argument that has `double` or `float` type's precision is not more than 6, and you must present it with 6 precision.

#### 3.
Arguments that has `int` type are always positive.
